original: Jonsson, Josef Petrus, tonsättare, musiklärare, Norrköping, f. 21/6/87 i Eniköp. av Per J. o. Anna Åberg. G. 1. 36 m. Emy Bentzer, d. 40; 2. 41 m. Ruth Ekelund. — Stud. pianospeln. 97-00, därefter självstud., sv. statens tonsättarstip. 17-21: 25 o. 27-47. Priv. musiklär. i Norrköp., musikanmäl. i östergöt’1. Folkblad sed. 22, medarb. i Sv. körförb. tidn. Vår Sång 31-45. Manuskr :verk: tre symf., två suiter f. ork., tre uvert., Herr Sten (ballad f. manskör o. ork.), kammarsymf., Preludio solenne. Musik. vign. f. stråkork.. Via dolorosa (påsiksvit f. stràkork.), Julrapsodi, Violinrom. ni. ork., tio kant.. Mitt land (f. solo, manskör o. ork.), sånger m. piano eller ork. o. pianost. Tryckta verk: Korallrevet (kÖrv.), En spelmans jordafärd o. Omkr. tiggaren fr. Luossa (melodra|mer). Missa Solemnis (f. kör o. ork.), ett 30-tal solosånger m. m. Litt. et Art. 37, Musikför. pris 39, LMA 38.
translated: Jonsson, Josef Petrus, composer, music teacher, from Norrköping. Born on June 21, 1887 in Eniköp to parents Per J. and Anna Åberg. Married 1) in 1936 to Emy Bentzer, who passed away in 1940, and 2) in 1941 to Ruth Ekelund. Studied piano from 1897-1900, and then self-studied and received the Swedish State Composer Scholarship from 1917-1921, 1925, 1927-1947. Private music teacher in Norrköping and music critic for the newspaper "Östergöt’1. Folkblad" since 1922. Contributor to the Swedish Choir Association's magazine "Vår Sång" from 1931-1945. Composed several works including three symphonies, two orchestral suites, three overtures, "Herr Sten" (ballad for men's choir and orchestra), a chamber symphony, "Preludio solenne", music vignettes for string orchestra, "Via dolorosa" (Easter suite for string orchestra), "Julrapsodi", "Violinrom" for orchestra, ten cantatas, "Mitt land" (for solo, men's choir and orchestra), and songs with piano or orchestra and piano accompaniment. Published works include "Korallrevet" (choral), "En spelmans jordafärd" and "Omkr. tiggaren fr. Luossa" (melodramas), "Missa Solemnis" (for choir and orchestra), and around 30 solo songs, among others. Awarded the Music Society Prize in 1939 and the Litteris et Artibus Medal in 1937, among other honors.
